subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: Continuing about testing private methods. What if a private method represent some kind of functionality that is needed only to this concrete class. You know
messageBody:
Continuing about testing private methods.

What if a private method represent some kind of functionality that is
needed only to this concrete class.

You know sometimes there is a big method which is not clearly readable.

So usually I extract some smaller pieces of code naming them
correspondingly.

So the code becomes more readable. But these methods are private and it
seems to me,

that there is no way to extract them to a separate class.



Consider this example:



public static Collection /* Flight */ search( FlightSearchParameters
params ) throws Exception

{

QS qs = Site.getSite().getUdeSession().getQS( Flight.TABLE_NAME );

StringBuffer whereString = new StringBuffer();

Collection whereParams = new ArrayList();

if ( params.getCityId() != null )

{

addDirectionFilter( params, whereString,
whereParams, "T_AIRPORT.XM_CITY_ID", params.getCityId() );

}

else

{

addDirectionFilter( params, whereString,
whereParams, "T_AIRPORT.M_ID", params.getAirportId() );

}

if ( params.getAirlineId() != null )

{

addAirlineFilter( whereString, whereParams,
params.getAirlineId() );

}

if ( params.getDate() != null )

{

addDateFilter( whereString, whereParams,
params.getDate() );

}

qs.setWhere( whereString.toString(), whereParams.toArray() );

qs.open();

while ( qs.next() )

{

results.add( Flight.getById( (String)
qs.getUnit().getPropertyValue( "ID" ) ) );

}

qs.close();

}



QS - is the analog of JDBC's Statement.

And methods like addXXXFilter just add some filtering conditions
(sometimes complex, it takes about 15-20 lines of code to construct em)
to 'where' clause of 'select' statement.



Anyway I'm not arguing to you, just want to know your opinion about this
case.

How do I test these all 'addXXXFilter' methods?

Or I don't need to test em at all (cause they are tested through the
test of 'public search(...)' method)??

Or may be you can suggest a better design solution?

Any help appreciated.



Thanks, Ilya.
